div.p: God be with us, beloved son, your letter and my letters have reached me well, and as you desire that I share with you the latest news that has come to me since, I have not received a single letter, so I cannot write anything to you. I have not yet heard of the king's death; I have heard that the king's people have been defeated; whether it is true, we will hear later.

Bellieure's speech, which he delivered in Baden before the 13 Cantons, is printed; for the people understand their cause to be printed; they think it will not go further than God wills. I have otherwise, before I knew of the printed speech, answered Bellieure's letter to me. I have also completed my book on the persecutions of the Christian church; whether it can be printed, I do not know.
I am quite surprised that I have not received a reply to my letter to Mr. Hans Conrad Ulmer in Schaffhausen. I have sent a lot of money there these days.

Hans Heinrich Lochman to Geneva, the poor exiles from France; Chur alone has sent me 122 florins. I thank you sincerely for your hare and veal, and I will also send you something in due time. Greet Susanna and the children for me; all my people greet you all. Dr. Burgower sends his sincere greetings. When I have something new, I will send it to you. I will inform you of the letters I have received from Glarus at another time and let you read them. I have letters from Heidelberg, dated December 21, but nothing special, except that Dr. Erastus has become rector and that Sylvanus is to be brought to justice before Christmas. Not a drop of good news from the Netherlands. The imperial envoys have left Poland without hope; the king is to be set for pacification; may God grant a good one; they consider the Muscovite. In 7 days, an Englishman will come here, saying all is well, and that the queen is brave. May God strengthen her and protect you.
Dated in haste amidst strong sneezing and headache, etc. January 15, 1573.
To my dear son Hans Rudolf Bullinger, pastor in Berg.
